content.description: Start 2-3 ft. right of the Bristling for Action Arete. Follow the face upwards.
Climb the large crack to the right of Stupid Route.
content.protection: Suitable trees for toprope anchors near top.
content.location: About in the middle of the crag, there's a 10 foot wide face between two very large parallel cracks.  Unwelcome Guest is the crack on the right.  Walk off left or right.

content.description: Climb the face between the cracks. Thin hands in places.  The name refers to comments made by those unable to make the moves.  You know who you are.
content.protection: Safest toproped.  Suitable trees near top for anchors.
content.location: About in the middle of the crag. A 10 foot wide face between two very large vertical cracks.  Walk off left or right.

content.description: Climb straight up the wide crack on the right.
content.protection: Standard rack with some larger cams.
content.location: At the far right of the crag, the cliff breaks in to an upper and lower section.  On the lower section, there are two large, distinctive, parallel vertical cracks.  Spine Tingler is the right.

content.description: Starting six to seven ft. right of Quill (just left of arete) climb upwards on face.
Two feet left of the Quill hemlock.
content.protection: Suitable trees for toprope anchors at top.

content.description: To the right of a large face and a good sized hemlock, follow the face with random blocks to the left of a large crack/gully. Use the arret if you must.
content.protection: Small TCUs and a set of nuts.

content.description: Three foot wide chimney infested with three trees.  Climb the outside of the chimney.  Included mostly as a reference point.
content.protection: Trees at top for TR anchors (bring long static).
content.location: Left side of crag.  Walk off left.

content.description:
Start directly beneath the 18" wide zigzag roof. Traverse left around the roof and finish off on the large vertical crack. 

  Var. Pull the roof and continue up (not 5.4).
content.protection: Standard rack with some small gear for the top.
content.location: Near center of crag, look for obvious left-facing roof topped by a large boulder.  The roof covers a flat face that is divided by 2 horizontal cracks.

content.description: Large crack on the far right side. Climb up into the hole, and if you are up to it, pull through the overhanging jam crack and stroll to the top. Committing moves with potential for ledge-fall.
Follow the face up midway between the Bristling Arete and the Hemlock tree.
Climb straight up the wide crack on the left.
content.protection: Standard rack with some larger cams.
content.location: At the far right of the crag, the cliff breaks in to an upper and lower section.  On the lower section, there are two large, distinctive, parallel vertical cracks.  Fissureman is the left.

content.protection: Suitable trees at top for anchors
content.location: Approximately in middle of crag.  It's just left of Stupid Route.  Walk off left or right.

content.description: A narrow chimney with one really big rectangular chockstone smack in the middle.
content.location: Around the corner on the far right of the crag. Look for the chockstone.

climbs.name: Dart Board
climbs.fa: Bob Clark, Bill Sullivan, Ken Nichols, June 1980

content.description: Climb the easiest line on the leftmost face.  The route runs where smoother rock on the left meets blockier rock on the right. A good warm-up.
content.protection: Suitable trees for toprope anchors at top (long webbing/static rope required).
content.location: At the far left of the crag.  Walk off left.

content.description: Wide-ish crack on the right wall of the needlepoint chimney. Nice jams along the crack at the far left arete.
Probably already has a real name (feel free to post it below), but it has a variety of choices of crack climbing style possible from hand jams to offwidth technique.
content.protection: Standard gear up to 3'', large tree at top for TR anchor.
content.location: This route is the obvious line to the right of Fissureman

content.description:
A short crag with a few good climbs.  This crag is typically shaded and makes for a nice summer crag when the days are longer.  The approach is somewhat longer than other cliffs in the area.  

  Long static or webbing for anchors is recommended. Please remember never to rap directly off trees. And when pulling ropes/webbing around trees try to make sure you're not wearing away the bark.
